rounds.response:
[GAME] Player 0, you are the Big Blind with 5♦ J♣ and must decide how to proceed after the Small Blind has already put in the full 20-chip bet (your 10 blind has been posted but it’s currently 20 to call).

Hand strength: Jack-5 offsuit is a modest drawing hand—good against random hands but behind stronger pairs/aces. Being out of position after the flop also reduces its value.

Options:
- Fold and give up your 10, leaving the pot to P1.
- Call 10 more chips to see the flop with a ~1.5-to-1 pot price.
- Raise to try to win the pot immediately and protect equity.

Best balance of risk/reward: The hand has enough equity to justify a cheap call with pot odds of 3:1 (only 10 to win 30). Folding wastes the posted blind; raising bloates the pot and leaves us out of position.

Action: [Call]

rounds.response:
I’m sitting in the small-blind (20 in already), heads-up with pocket 9’s. No other cards are out.  

Pocket 9’s is a very strong starting hand two-handed—way ahead of any un-paired starting hands my opponent could have, and even against a 30 % range we’re ~55-60 % equity pre-flop. Because the pot is already 30 (including my SB + his BB / limp) and he has only a 20-to-call open, I’m going to pot-build with a standard 3-bet here. Two-handed I’ll make it 3× his original open, so 3 × 20 = 60 total, an additional 40 on top of the 20 I’ve already put out.

[Raise 40]

rounds.response:
I'm on the river with 9♠ 9♥, the board is 5♣ 5♥ J♣ 6♥ 10♠, I'm heads-up, and the pot is 700.  
With no flush possibilities and my pocket nines I have exactly two pair on the board (fives) and one high card. There’s a risk that my opponent has a straight (7-8), a higher over-pair, or J-x for a higher two pair.  

Because (a) the board offers several obvious draws that could now credit an opponent with a straight, and (b) I don’t want to risk another 600+ chips when an over-kill bet might get snap-called by a better hand, I’ll get maximum value (and limit losses) by not betting. I’m last to act (the BB already checked).  

[Check]

I’m holding 10♥ 10♦ – a premium pocket pair – and I’ve just been 3-bet out of the BB to 230 by an opponent who now has only 410 behind (and is effectively pot-committed). Performed a quick reckoning:

• 12 combos of overpairs (AA/KK/QQ/JJ) are possible.
• 16 combos of AK, 4 of AQ suited that might raise pre-flop.
• About 6–8 combos of two-suited aces/SCs.

Against this range I’m a modest favorite to flip with unpaired hands (55-65% equity) and only a slight underdog (≈20% vs higher pairs). More importantly, the SPR on the flop will be 1.2 – plunging ranges into all-in land, and every big pot I lose here cripples me versus the much shorter rival. With no stack to punish me post-flop, shove-and-win dominates any street-by-street plan.

Decision:

[Raise 610]
